title: Example Document with Review Extension
text: Features

title: Debug Mode Example
text:
This document demonstrates how to enable debug mode for the Quarto Review extension. Debug output will appear in your browser‚Äôs Developer Console.



Open Developer Console:

Windows/Linux: Press F12 or Ctrl+Shift+I
macOS: Press Cmd+Option+I

Go to Console Tab:

Click the ‚ÄúConsole‚Äù tab in Developer Tools

Look for Debug Messages:

Messages will show module name, timestamp, and debug info
Example: [DEBUG] [17:45:23.456] [UIModule] Component initialized







Click on any paragraph to edit it. You should see debug messages like: - Opening editor for [element-id] - Markdown updated: [content]
Example paragraph: This is a paragraph you can edit. Double-click to open the editor and watch the debug output.



Single-click to add a comment. Watch for: - Comment composer opened - Comment added: [timestamp]



Press Cmd+F (or Ctrl+F) to search. Look for: - Search panel opened - Matches found: [count]




This document uses this configuration:
review:
  debug:
    enabled: true
    level: debug
    modules:
      - UIModule
      - ChangesModule
    format-timestamp: true



enabled: true - Debug mode is active
level: debug - Show detailed information (not just errors/warnings)
modules - Only log these modules to reduce noise
format-timestamp: true - Include time in each message





Change level to see different amounts of output:
# Just errors and warnings
level: warn

# General information only
level: info

# Detailed debugging info (current)
level: debug

# Everything (most verbose)
level: trace



You can configure which modules to log:
modules:
  - UIModule              # User interface
  - ChangesModule         # Change tracking
  - CommentsModule        # Comments
  - MarkdownModule        # Markdown rendering
  - GitModule             # Git operations
  - UserModule            # Authentication
  - KeyboardShortcuts     # Keyboard commands
  - DocumentSearch        # Search functionality



Reduce noise by excluding certain modules:
exclude-modules:
  - GitModule         # Git often very verbose
  - KeyboardShortcuts # Too many events



Debug mode has minimal performance impact: - Only enabled when enabled: true - Filtering reduces overhead - Can be disabled quickly for testing
When done debugging, remove the review.debug section from your YAML.



Try editing this bullet list and watch the debug output:

Item one: Try editing this text
Item two: Double-click to enter edit mode
Item three: Watch the console for debug messages




Try adding a comment:
Single-click on any text element and select ‚ÄúAdd comment‚Äù from the quick menu. The console will show comment-related debug messages.




Press Cmd+F (or Ctrl+F)
Type a word to search for
Watch the console for search debug output




For complete documentation, see: docs/user/DEBUG.md


If you need to change debug settings after loading:
// In browser console:

// Enable debug mode
window.debugLogger.enable('debug')

// Disable debug mode
window.debugLogger.disable()

// Change configuration
window.debugLogger.setConfig({
  modules: ['UIModule'],
  level: 'trace'
})

// Show debug help
window.printDebugHelp()





‚úÖ Open Developer Console (F12)
‚úÖ Try editing content above
‚úÖ Watch debug messages appear
‚úÖ Try different actions (comments, search, etc.)
‚úÖ Modify the review.debug config to try different settings
‚úÖ Read docs/user/DEBUG.md for complete documentation

Happy debugging! üêõ
